Hey gang, it's been a while since I posted here, but I had this idea. Little known facts and tidbits of info on various subjects of any interest I like to call:
 
 
 
 TRIVIAL TRIVIA
 
 The idea is simple. Ask a question about a little known fact about anything, let someone try to answer, and come back with the correct answer (unless, of course the poster answers correctly).
 
 
 OK I'll start. Which Major League umpire possessed the largest strike zone in the league??

Hey gang, it's been a while since I posted here, but I had this idea. Little known facts and tidbits of info on various subjects of any interest I like to call:
 
 
 
 TRIVIAL TRIVIA
 
 The idea is simple. Ask a question about a little known fact about anything, let someone try to answer, and come back with the correct answer (unless, of course the poster answers correctly).
 
 
 OK I'll start. Which Major League umpire possessed the largest strike zone in the league??

 
 
 How was this measured? Today's Marlins-Nationals umpire seems to have a pretty big strike zone, but you can't exactly quantify how big a strike zone is unless you're talking about K-zone and such.

 I'm just going for a guess here: Lou Gehrig. I have nothing to go on except for the fact that he was one of the old time players (back when baseball was more well respected than it is now.) But since mostly what I know is the plan out of the game and some of the teams and where people go, I don't personally have much to go on.
 
 
 But nothing was said that this has to be limited to sports, so here's a trivial song question from me:
 
 In Bob Seger's "Night Moves," Seger says that he "started humming a song from 1962."
 What was that song that Bob Seger was quoted as referencing in "Night Moves?"

In Bob Seger's "Night Moves," Seger says that he "started humming a song from 1962."
 What was that song that Bob Seger was quoted as referencing in "Night Moves?"

 
 
 My guess would be "In the Summertime" by Mungo Jerry.

Must a question be answered correctly before another question is asked?
 
 For example, if I have no clue as to the answer of the current question, can I ask one of my own? I'm afraid that such a policy will lead to too many questions and too few answers.
 
 Perhaps:
 - When three incorrect guesses have been submitted, the questioner reveals the answer, then asks another question, unless
 - When a question is answered correctly, the respondent asks a question of his/her own
 
 (Now for the irony: by asking the question above, I am violating the potential guidelines I spelled out above...)

Must a question be answered correctly before another question is asked?
 
 For example, if I have no clue as to the answer of the current question, can I ask one of my own? I'm afraid that such a policy will lead to too many questions and too few answers.
 
 Perhaps:
 - When three incorrect guesses have been submitted, the questioner reveals the answer, then asks another question, unless
 - When a question is answered correctly, the respondent asks a question of his/her own
 
 (Now for the irony: by asking the question above, I am violating the potential guidelines I spelled out above...)

 Which is what I've intended. I should have been more clear on this. But yes, if say three incorrect guesses, then the questioner gives the correct answer then asks another question. If, however the respondent answers correctly, then (s)he can ask the next question.

My guess would be "In the Summertime" by Mungo Jerry.

 The song that Bob Seger is quoted as refering to is "Be My Baby" by The Ronettes.
 
 
 Hopefully, this clears it up now for the next question.
Here's one for all the die-hard Trekkies (like me) out there. Name the actor who played a Vulcan, a Klingon, and a Romulan.

Here's one for all the die-hard Trekkies (like me) out there. Name the actor who played a Vulcan, a Klingon, and a Romulan.

 First name that comes to mind is [the late] Mark Lenard.
 
 He played Spock's father, Sarek.
 He played a Romulan in the original series episode "Ballance Of Terror."
 I believe he played a Klingon in Star Trek The Motion Picture.

 Welcome back, zachvac.
 
 Way back when, Harvey Haddix pitched a perfect game into the 12th (13th?) inning and lost. I believe he is credited with a perfect game even though the entire game was not perfect.
 
 I think he also said after the game something like, "Hasn't anyone else ever lost a 12 (13?) inning shutout?"
 
 ETA: zachvac isn't the only one with trivial trivia about baseball...

What haloacid must be stored in plastic because it etches glass?

Okay, it appears that my geeky chemistry question didn't go over too well, so -- as it has been 20 hours -- I will reveal the answer and present a less evil one.
 
 Hydrofluoric acid (chemical formula HF) can be stored in plastic, but cannot be stored in glass because it reacts with the silicon therein.
